I think you should edit the video to tell people that the sign of work is purely convention. In physical chemistry, We say the system does negative work, and the surroundings do positive work on the system.  I remember someone say that in engineering, they use DU = Q-W because they care about what the system can do for them, thus positive work done by the system but in studying the system they use DU = Q + W because they care about what is happening to the system.  Nuance.

He mentions this in his “first law of thermodynamics” video. In thermodynamics, we take the POV of the surroundings. In chemistry, we take the POV of the system.

@louis-philipeespinosa1288   Because in thermodynamics we care about the direction of energy transfer; so work done by system to surr is negative because energy is "lost" by the system. And work done by surr to system is positive because the system gains energy.  But in chemistry, we care about what the system is capable of: so if a reaction proceeds exothermically and generates heat that does work, then w = positive. work done on the system from this POV is negative because we are essentially storing energy, which will be harnessed to do work. That's true in chemistry thermodynamic but opposite in physics thermodynamic 👌 https://youtu.be/NyOYW07-L5g

@norah..  Exactly. The difference lies in how the first law is defined in both disciplines. delta U = Q + W by convention in most chemistry contexts, but delta U = Q - W by convention in most physics contexts.

Don't know if you still care about this but...the form of the formula that you are referencing is for W (W = -n*cv*delta T). Note that the expression for change in internal energy is always delta U = n*cv*delta T. Because W = -U (or equivalently U = -W) for an adiabatic process, THAT is where we get the negative sign W = -n*cv*delta T.

To be clear, Q + W is a state function so long as Q is defined as the heat transferred INTO the system and W is defined as work done ON a system.  Short Answer:  If ΔU = Q + W, ΔU (a state function) can be related to Q–W by the relation Q–W = (Q + W)–2W = ΔU–2W. Although ΔU is a state function W is not. W is a path-dependent quantity in that, the amount of work done ON a system going from state A to state B depends on the path taken. Whereas the sum (or product) of two state functions is also a state function (ΔG = ΔH–TΔS), the sum of a state function and a path-dependent quantity is not. Thus, the sum of these two terms cannot be a state function.  Long Answer:  Consider two arbitrary processes that take a system from the same initial state (state A) to the same final state (state B). The change in internal energy for process 1 can be written as ΔU1 = Q1 + W1. The change in internal energy for process 2 can be written as ΔU2 = Q2 + W2. We can also write expressions for Q–W for each process using the relation Q–W = ΔU–2W. For process 1, Q1–W1 = ΔU1–2W1. For process 2, Q2–W2 = ΔU–2W2.  In order for a quantity for be considered a state function, it must be path-independent. This means that for any two arbitrary processes that take the system from the same initial state to the same final state, the change in that quantity must be the same.  Suppose Q–W is a state function. Then, it must be the same for our two processes. In other words, Q1–W1 = Q2–W2. This can also be written as ΔU1–2W1 = ΔU2–2W2. Because the processes take the system from the same initial and final states and because ΔU is a state function, ΔU1 = ΔU2. Thus, we can cancel out ΔU1 and ΔU2 from their respective sides. We're left with –2W1 = –2W2. But in general, W1 and W2 will not be the same because as I mentioned before, work is a path-dependent quantity. Therefore, Q–W is not a state function despite the fact that Q + W is.

@Bbbbbbbbbbhhhhhhh  Basically, stick to your studies and a regular schedule, you'll be fine.   I won't sugar coat it, unless you're massively passionate about the engineering subject you're going into, then you're not going to get the typical "best years of your life" student experience. While I enjoy the aerospace sector 100%, boiling it down to numbers gets old very fast. On the surface, it's very interesting, but when it gets to the numbers, you're nearly guaranteed to find at least 50%+ of it a pain in the arse.   Most engineers end up in a very specific section of their industry, and universities can't just show you that very specific part you may end up doing. So instead you'll of course cover a wide array of topics and you'll find a good amount of it a ballache.   You'll be tired, a lot. There'll be weekends where you don't get to rest because of 3 assignments, maybe week after week. Because of the tiredness, you'll probably also fall behind on lectures by a week or two sometimes. And because of that, you won't be living some ideal student life you may have been told is possible.   BUT, it remains Aerospace. At the end of the day, I am studying in detail some of the coolest shit on the planet. And for the 50% boring shit you'll end up doing, there'll be a good 50% where you think, damn, this is actually kinda cool. And after it's all said and done, once your get your degree, you'll end up reaping the profits of your hard work and sacrificed social life.  Could I have picked something easier? Without a doubt. It would've been a hell of a lot less stress (a HELL of a lot less). But at least this way, 10, 20, 50 years down the line, I won't be thinking "what if I actually went as ambitious as Aerospace engineering".

DEMONIC programming: a computational language for single-particle equilibrium thermodynamics, and its formal Semantics:   Also, Maxwell's Demon, 'a being whose faculties are so sharpened that he can follow every molecule in its course', has been the centre of much debate about its abilities to violate the second law of thermodynamics. Landauer's hypothesis, that the Demon must erase its memory and incur a thermodynamic cost, has become the standard response to Maxwell's dilemma, and its implications for the thermodynamics of computation reach into many areas of quantum and classical computing. Landauer’s hypothesis was introduced to get around the problem of Maxwell’s Demon: a diabolic entity who could apparently violate the second law of thermodynamics within a closed system.  The second law of thermodynamics, in one of its formulations, states that within a closed system the quantity entropy is non-decreasing over time. Some processes are only allowed to operate in one temporal direction. This appears to conflict with underlying reversible microdynamics, either quantum or classical Newtonian. Since the formulation of thermodynamics, toy model thermodynamic systems have been used in debates around these foundational issues. The simplest example is a single particle in a box, in contact with a heat bath. The thermodynamic variables can be easily specified, while at the same time the microdynamics for the single particle are easily comprehensible. While there are important issues around whether this system can actually be said to have a thermodynamics (usually considered a theory of large numbers of particles), it is a useful tool and the form of system that has been considered by a large number of authors from Szilard. By formalising this system, we also give a starting-point for a similar semantics of many-particle thermodynamic systems. The fundamental system under consideration is a single particle gas in a box, connected to an external heat bath. The heat bath keeps the entire system at a specific temperature T; this is a constant and not a variable. The thermodynamic variables for the system are: pressure of the gas (i.e. the force exerted on the walls of the box by the continuous motion of the single particle) p, volume occupied by the gasV, and entropy of the system H. There is a removable partition in the middle of the box, and two pistons (left and right) which can either compress the gas and input work −W into the system (isothermal compression) or expand under pressure of the gas thereby extracting work W from the box (isothermal expansion). There are two fundamental equations of state for the system: pV/ T =const Hout −Hin =kln Vout /Vin  where again k is the Bolzmann constant, and where ‘out’ and ‘in’ refer respectively to output and input values of parameters for a given transition. The first means that pressure and volume are not independent at a fixed temperature; only one variable need be specifed. The second equation means that a decrease in system volume of a half decreases the entropy of the system by kln2. A doubling of the system volume increases the entropy by the same amount. In isothermal expansion from volumeV → 2V, the amount of work done by the gas on the piston isW =kT ln2. In isothermal compression 2V →V, the same amount of work is input to the gas by the piston.

Hey! Idk which part of the vid it is but just wanted to clarify if anyone is wondering the same thing. There's heat capacity depending on mass, m(cp and cv, small "c" letters), and heat capacity depending on Molar mass(Cp and Cv, capital "c" letters). Depending on that we get two formulas,  Qv = m*cv*(T2-T1) = n*Cv*(T2-T1), where n is the number of moles. And, Qp = m*cp*(T2-T1) = n*Cp*(T2-T1).  You can also use more formulas for Qv/Qp, if you need them I'll write them down.

For a monoatomic gas, [5/2 R] is the Cp, while [3/2 R] is the Cv. Cp is used in the equation Q = n Cp dT where Q (heat transfer) is being calculated. However in this case, dU (change in internal energy) is being calculated, where dU = n Cv dT is used, so [3/2 R] is correct.
